comments:
Nursing 064 explores experimental techniques of cell biology and microbiology, with emphasis on cellular processes, cultivation and characterization of bacteria and the relationship of these to pathological events. Laboratory exercises include the study of cellular organelles, main biological macromolecules, enzymes and antibodies, cellular transport, pH and acid/base balance, the spread and control of infectious organism, bacterial identification, identification of mutagens and antibiotic sensitivity, amplification and identification of genes using PCR and DNA sequencing. Students will learn to work effectively in groups to perform experiments, record observations, analyze results and relate these results to health care related topics.

Many students criticize that although this course is presented as lab, there are no real components. One student pointed out everything is “virtual and theoretical,” asserting that this was not conducive to learning.

This course is taught by a variety of lab TAs.

This course is taken concurrently with NURS 063. It is required for nursing students in freshman year.

*Nursing 064 explores experimental techniques of cell biology and microbiology, with emphasis on cellular processes, cultivation and characterization of bacteria and the relationship of these to pathological events. Laboratory exercises include the study of cellular organelles, main biological macromolecules, enzymes and antibodies, cellular transport, pH and acid/base balance, the spread and control of infectious organism, bacterial identification, identification of mutagens and antibiotic sensitivity, amplification and identification of genes using PCR and DNA sequencing. Students learn to work effectively in groups to perform experiments, record observations, analyze results and relate these results to health care related topics.

Students were disappointed that this course was not a hands-on lab, but rather a computer simulation. They complained that it involved too much “busywork,” which did not provide much benefit to the students, though some commented that it had the potential to be interesting.

One student commented that Professor Wislowski was too “vague” when teaching the material. 

The final was regarded as unfair and students felt unprepared due to the hypothetical nature of instruction throughout the semester. 

*This review is based on seven student reviews
